author: SealCub-ClubbingClub
body:
Yeah OP has completely misread this. AMD, Apple, Qualcomm are all using TSMC fab and are all moving between 7nm EUV and 5nm EUV nodes.

OP should be buying TSMC (or ASML) if it's the process that they are impressed by because they are the ones that produced it, Apple is just a customer.

Edit: Also it's not the chip that's 5nm it's just the name of the fab process and is roughly indicative of the transistor size. Really the properties that matter for a chip (outside of just how good the design is) are the chip area (in mm^2), transistor count (which is a function of transistor size) and yield (which is a function of size & process)

author: rightovahere
body:
If you're a multinational that does business in a foreign country or region, you need to comply by that regions laws. You can't just tell a country to fuck off unless you want to be barred from doing business in that country for an indefinite period of time.

Nobody gives a fuck if Paraguay tells Nvidia that they'll have a monopoly, but they sure do if the USA or CN does.

China killed the qualcomm NXP merger a few years back due to antitrust concerns (and potentially some trade war fuckery), and that wasn't nearly as excessive compared to this. Nvidia controlling ARM would be insane.

author: GadnukBreakerOfWrlds
body:
*Public Service Announcement*:  
  
Most of the leading fabless semiconductor companies such as **Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), Apple Inc., Broadcom Inc., Marvell, MediaTek, Nvidia, and Qualcomm** are customers of TSMC, as well as emerging companies such as Allwinner Technology, HiSilicon, Spectra7, and Spreadtrum. Leading programmable logic device companies Xilinx and previously Altera also make or made use of TSMC's foundry services. Some integrated device manufacturers that have their own fabrication facilities like **Intel, STMicroelectronics and Texas Instruments** outsource some of their production to TSMC.  
  
#TSM

author: meeni131
body:
While I think the Apple Silicon may be strong for Apple, how much will this affect the significant applications of ARM? 

Apple has a 13% phone market share and a 10% laptop market share. They have mentioned that being based on ARM is not your standard ARM; so Apple stands alone as they add many features not present in other ARM chips (and are better than qualcomm etc). 

ARM-based servers seem like they may hit a 10-15% market share in 5-8 years but right now they're extremely negligible. 

Seems like Apple may help drive more ARM adoption in some applications but it doesn't seem to me like it'll matter in the medium run at this point for the dominance of Intel/AMD over ARM in CPUs.

Intel was supposedly having fab problems with 7 nm, so they are actually using TSMC to fab some chips.  That’s why intel’s stock dropped.  Is it a good time to buy? I have no idea. author: ixamnis
body:
Broad Market:  That's tough to say.  If your very bullish on Tech stocks, QQQ might be your best bet. If you want a broader fund, then VOO is a good one.  QQQ uses the NASDAQ 100 as its bench mark while VOO uses the S&P 500 as its benchmark. The top five holdings are the same for each of these, but in different percentages.  Another broad market fund I like is IWF. IWF uses the Russell 1000 as its benchmark.  It has a very good track record and seems to outperform the S&P 500 over time. It's very similar to QQQ in its holdings, but again, percentages are slightly different.  You can't go wrong with any of these choices for a broad market fund. 

Tech:  You'll get lots of opinions on this.  ARKQ and ARKW would be the choice of the ARK funds if you want it to be purely tech.  If you want to invest in disruptive innovative companies, but don't mind expanding beyond tech, consider ARKK. 

Another one I like for tech is XLK. However, you have to keep in mind that XLK is almost 25% Apple and 25% Microsoft.  If you believe in those two companies, consider this one.  (VGT is very similar). 

SOXX is a fund that invests in semiconductor technology. One thing I like about this fund is that there will not be a lot of crossover between this one and your broad market fund.  Top holdings include: QCOM (9.5%), NVDA (9.5%), AVGO (8.3%), TXN (8%), INTC (5%). 

WCLD:  Cloud computing is a great sector, but be aware that many of these companies will also be in QQQ.  Top holdings include ZM (2.4%), CRM (2.3%), PLAN (2.2%), CRWD (2.1%), WDAY (2.1%). One thing I like about this ETF is that the investments are much more spread out than most ETFs. So, if any one company in the ETF is affected by bad news, it should have little impact on the ETF as a whole. I think WCLD is an excellent choice. 

Clean Energy ETF:  I like ICLN like many others on this site.  I think the clean/renewable energy sector is really going to blossom over the next 10 years and I think ICLN is one of the better ETFs in the sector. Others you may want to look into include:  PBW, QCLN and TAN.

author: Shulz87
body:
My main concern is mostly that he doesn't follow the stock market much and has a bunch of random stocks. It wasn't anything he picked, was inherited. He's had it for over a year and thought it was doing great. I looked at it and almost everything is down 15% and Apple is up 100%. So for a year all he was looking at was how his portfolio was doing overall. Once Apple started going down the portfolio was going down much harder than the market last two weeks so I looked at it. Then I noticed close to 20% Altria in it and 30% Apple. Then it's about 7-10% each of Qualcomm, JPM, and PM, AEP, and Verizon Then a few more at like 1%-5%. Portfolio is all over the place and it just makes me nervous if he's not going to be hands on with individual stocks. Also in a taxable account Altria and some of the other higher dividend stocks are going to be taxed. Over 7 or so years that's going to add up. Especially if the stock isn't moving or is going down steadily. 

For now what he's going to do is stick with the portfolio but I mentioned to him to keep on top of these stocks. I think that as the dividends get reinvested that'll lower his cost basis and also if the stock itself goes up that'll lower his loss on it. Once some of the stocks are closet to break even he can look to get out of them for ETFs. I gave him a few to look into and see the top 10 holdings. I think he would be better off in the long run with stuff like VYM and SCHD along with building his current ETF positions. It would be different if these were hand-picked stocks but he inherited it and then all he did for a year was look at Apple going on an all time high.

author: moneygardener
body:
debt/eq ratio only tells you so much. They have announced that they will use TSMC to manufacture some limited amount of some, or one, of their chips.

If they can't solve their problems reaching sub 10 nm, and competing with TSMC, they would maybe have to do like AMD and go fabless. This means a massive write-off on a big portion of their assets, suddenly making the asset part of the debt equation look much worse. That's basically admitting defeat in the cutting edge manufacturing aspect of chips, making their investors loose a lot of faith in them.

I'm not saying this will happen, but the risk of it happening, means that I will not take the chance.

A safer bet IMO would be TSMC ($TSM)

Most of the leading fabless semiconductor companies such as AMD, Apple, Broadcom., Marvell, MediaTek, Nvidia, and Qualcomm are or were customers of TSMC.

&#x200B;

A ***riskier*** bet, but with higher upside, is AMD.

author: futbolito112000
body:
I had NOK at $4 and sold at $5 after earnings. I also sold options on the shares I owned ($5 call). I believe in the company but people have been burned in the past so they are hesitant to invest in it. They are still restructuring and their products cost more than the other players; however, that should change in 6 or 9 months. Their data center seems promising too and I believe Apple is a customer.  To be honest, it's probably dead money for awhile and it's going to be in this $4 to $5 range. I wouldn't be surprised if it dips under $4.  Maybe pick up 250 shares and sell when it goes up a quarter and wait for pullbacks or hold on for the long term in case they get acquired. Other than that, you are better off with Marvell Technologies, Apple, Qrvo, Qualcomm for a 5G play. Even if you get less shares for $1000, the likelihood of the stock moving up is much greater. Also, if they pay dividends (Apple pays divs but not sure of the others), just reinvest the dividends and you will have more shares in the future. I've been burned by a lot of these cheap stocks that they are almost not worth investing in because they just don't move much.  You can consider having a portfolio of 6 of these under $7 stocks but don't put more than $3k. If one of them pans out, great. Not all will be winners.  

You may want to consider Ark Invest ETFs as I have a couple of them (ARKK and ARKF). The returns have been tremendous and Cathy (CEO) invests in disruptive companies. Vanguard funds are good too and I am considering getting one of the cloud ETFs and information technology ETFs when the market pulls back again as valuations are still too high. I may also look at the IPO ETF and getting some Snowflake (SNOW) shares for the long term. Good luck and I agree to not day trade with your IRA and take profits when the stocks/ETFs climb as you can buy them back again. Try to sell option calls if you have 100 shares for some additional passive income.

TSMC manufactures chips for most of these guys. They have state of the art manufacturing facilities. It is staying around $80 for some time even during big tech sell off. AMD and INTL are x86 compute group. NVDA, AVGO, QCOM and MRVL are ARM group. I would say buy all of them. Then there are bunch  of diversified group. I would say split investment into few of them. Never know what happens in tech.

intel, cisco, qualcomm, juniper etc were all huge bubble stocks in the tech bubble and were making tons of money.

author: BumbleFuckDuck
body:
Article from link:

"Zomedica Pharmaceuticals Corp. (NYSE American: ZOM) announced today that it has agreed with its development partner Qorvo Biotechnologies, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Qorvo US, Inc., to develop three new assays -- Cobalamin, cPL (canine Pancreatic Lipase), and Folate -- to target diagnosis of canine gastrointestinal issues. The new assays are in addition to the initial five assays currently under development, including panels for adrenal and thyroid testing, for TRUFORMA™, Zomedica's point-of-care veterinary diagnostic platform. The agreement to pursue development of the new assays has triggered the final $2 million milestone payment under Zomedica’s Development and Supply Agreement with Qorvo.

“Our intent for TRUFORMA™ always has been to have it serve as a broad diagnostic point-of-care tool for dogs and cats and to continue to expand the diagnostic offerings available on the platform," said Robert Cohen, Interim Chief Executive Officer of Zomedica. "We believe that the combination of the Cobalamin, cPL and Folate assays will enable veterinarians to use TRUFORMA to conduct a thorough testing panel to diagnose dogs in gastrointestinal distress."

If successfully developed, the Cobalamin, cPL, and Folate assays will represent what the Company believes is the first non-infectious gastrointestinal panel optimized for use in canines fully available at the point-of-care to facilitate rapid diagnosis of gastrointestinal disorders. Evaluation of the health of different components of the gastrointestinal system is necessary to identify the cause of clinical symptoms. This panel is intended to assay the function of the pancreas, proximal small intestine, and distal small intestine. The Company believes that the ability to conduct testing at the point-of-care will facilitate real-time clinical decision-making, reduce in-patient clinic stay, promote earlier detection and treatment, and increase pet owner satisfaction.

According to a DVM360 study*, ASPCA Pet Insurance, Embrace, Nationwide, Pets Best and Trupanion agree that “GI condition” is the most common insurance claim for dogs. Signs of digestive system disease can include excessive drooling, diarrhea, constipation, vomiting or regurgitation, loss of appetite, bleeding, abdominal pain and bloating, straining to defecate, shock, and dehydration. The TRUFORMA diagnostic device, which is smaller than a desktop printer, is anticipated to provide highly sensitive, species-specific assays using Qorvo’s proprietary, non-optical Bulk Acoustic Wave ("BAW") sensor technology. The BAW sensor is a proven semiconductor technology used in telecommunications and aerospace markets. The Company believes that BAW technology has the potential to improve veterinary diagnostics by delivering reference laboratory accuracy and test performance to the veterinary clinic at the point-of-care."

I bolded the important parts. This is a long hold regardless if r/s happens or does not. IMO the r/s ain't happening.
